    Applied Probability
    Part II, 2002

    Two enthusiastic probability students, Ros and Guil, sit an examination which starts at time 0 and ends at time TTT; they both decide to use the time to attempt a proof of a difficult theorem which carries a lot of extra marks.

    Ros' strategy is to write the proof continuously at a constant speed λ\lambdaλ lines per unit time. In a time interval of length δt\delta tδt he has a probability μδt+o(δt)\mu \delta t+o(\delta t)μδt+o(δt) of realising he has made a mistake. If that happens he instantly panics, erases everything he has written and starts all over again.

    Guil, on the other hand, keeps cool and thinks carefully about what he is doing. In a time interval of length δt\delta tδt, he has a probability λδt+o(δt)\lambda \delta t+o(\delta t)λδt+o(δt) of writing the next line of proof and for each line he has written a probability μδt+o(δt)\mu \delta t+o(\delta t)μδt+o(δt) of finding a mistake in that line, independently of all other lines he has written. When a mistake is found, he erases that line and carries on as usual, hoping for the best.

    Both Ros and Guil realise that, even if they manage to finish the proof, they will not recognise that they have done so and will carry on writing as much as they can.

    (a) Calculate pl(t)p_{l}(t)pl​(t), the probability that, for Ros, the length of his completed proof at time t⩾l/λt \geqslant l / \lambdat⩾l/λ is at least lll.

    (b) Let qn(t)q_{n}(t)qn​(t) be the probability that Guil has nnn lines of proof at time t>0t>0t>0. Show that

    ∂Q∂t=(s−1)(λQ−μ∂Q∂s)\frac{\partial Q}{\partial t}=(s-1)\left(\lambda Q-\mu \frac{\partial Q}{\partial s}\right) ∂t∂Q​=(s−1)(λQ−μ∂s∂Q​)

    where Q(s,t)=∑n=0∞snqn(t)Q(s, t)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} s^{n} q_{n}(t)Q(s,t)=∑n=0∞​snqn​(t).

    (c) Suppose now that every time Ros starts all over again, the time until the next mistake has distribution FFF, independently of the past history. Write down a renewal-type integral equation satisfied by l(t)l(t)l(t), the expected length of Ros' proof at time ttt. What is the expected length of proof produced by him at the end of the examination if FFF is the exponential distribution with mean 1/μ1 / \mu1/μ ?

    (d) What is the expected length of proof produced by Guil at the end of the examination if each line that he writes survives for a length of time with distribution FFF, independently of all other lines?

  • 3.II.25I

    Applied Probability
    Part II, 2005

    Consider an M/G/r/0\mathrm{M} / \mathrm{G} / r / 0M/G/r/0 loss system with arrival rate λ\lambdaλ and service-time distribution FFF. Thus, arrivals form a Poisson process of rate λ\lambdaλ, service times are independent with common distribution FFF, there are rrr servers and there is no space for waiting. Use Little's Lemma to obtain a relation between the long-run average occupancy LLL and the stationary probability π\piπ that the system is full.

    Cafe-Bar Duo has 23 serving tables. Each table can be occupied either by one person or two. Customers arrive either singly or in a pair; if a table is empty they are seated and served immediately, otherwise, they leave. The times between arrivals are independent exponential random variables of mean 20/320 / 320/3. Each arrival is twice as likely to be a single person as a pair.     Applied Probability
    Part II, 2021

    (a) Customers arrive at a queue at the event times of a Poisson process of rate λ\lambdaλ. The queue is served by two independent servers with exponential service times with parameter μ\muμ each. If the queue has length nnn, an arriving customer joins with probability rnr^{n}rn and leaves otherwise (where r∈(0,1])\left.r \in(0,1]\right)r∈(0,1]). For which λ>0,μ>0\lambda>0, \mu>0λ>0,μ>0 and r∈(0,1]r \in(0,1]r∈(0,1] is there a stationary distribution?

    (b) A supermarket allows a maximum of NNN customers to shop at the same time. Customers arrive at the event times of a Poisson process of rate 1 , they enter the supermarket when possible, and they leave forever for another supermarket otherwise. Customers already in the supermarket pay and leave at the event times of an independent Poisson process of rate μ\muμ. When is there a unique stationary distribution for the number of customers in the supermarket? If it exists, find it.

    (c) In the situation of part (b), started from equilibrium, show that the departure process is Poissonian.
